transcript.text: Okay, let’s start. Bob, can you walk us through auth?
Sure. Login and token generation are done. Using env-based secrets.
Wait, I thought the JWT secret was hardcoded in the auth file?
No, it’s pulled from the environment.
Oh… I was editing the code thinking that’s where it lives.
That’s a misunderstanding. Secrets never live in code.
Got it. That wasn’t clear to me earlier.
I just need to know if the login endpoint is stable now.
Yes, API is ready.
Should auth activity be counted in contribution metrics?
Not for now. Let’s park that.
This is the sprint review before client demo. Charlie?
Dashboard is mostly done. User view works well.
Where’s the admin analytics panel?
That’s not ready yet. I underestimated the effort.
Backend APIs were done last week.
The client specifically asked for role-based views this sprint.
I know. I missed the timeline.
I didn’t realize that part was client-critical.
That’s on planning, but missing the demo hurts trust.
This is a retrospective. Let’s be honest.
I noticed some commits were fast but came from shared snippets.
Yeah, the login logic was adapted from what Ethan shared on Slack.
Which is fine, but we didn’t document that properly.
I didn’t ask questions early and assumed things. That caused confusion.
I underestimated complexity and stayed quiet about delays.
Both of those caused real issues, wrong assumptions and missed deadlines.
This is why commit count alone doesn’t reflect contribution.
Agreed. Reviews and guidance matter too.
